site.title: Online String Tools – Simple, free and easy to use string utilities
site.meta_desc: World's simplest collection of useful string utilities. Hundreds of tools for encoding, decoding, converting, filtering, replacing, generating strings, and much more.
site.front_page_intro: Online string tools offers a collection of useful string manipulation utilities. All string tools are simple and easy to use, and they all work exactly the same way – you just have to load your string in the input area of a tool and you'll instantly get the result in the output area. Created by team Browserling.
site.credit_text: We're Browserling — a friendly and fun cross-browser testing company powered by alien technology. At Browserling we love to make peoples' lives easier, so we created this collection of online string tools. All our tools share the same user interface so as soon as you learn how to use one of the tools, you'll instantly know how to use all of them. Our online string tools are actually powered by our web developer tools that we created over the last couple of years. Check them out!

tools.title: URL-encode a String
tools.name: String URL Encoder
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that URL-encodes a string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string URL escaper. Load a string and get it URL-encoded.
tools.long_desc: Free online string URL-encoder. Just load your string and it will automatically get URL-escaped. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string URL-escaper. Load a string, get a URL-encoded string. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly URL-escape a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool URL-encodes a string. Special URL characters get converted to percent-sign encoding. This encoding is called percent-encoding because each character's numeric value gets converted to a percent sign followed by a two-digit hexadecimal value. The hex values are determined based on the character's codepoint value. For example, a space gets escaped to %20, a colon to %3a, a slash to %2f. Characters that are not special stay unchanged. In case you also need to convert non-special characters to percent-encoding, then we've also added an extra option that lets you do that. Select the encode-non-special-chars option to enable this behavior. Stringabulous!

examples.title: URL-escape a Short Message
examples.description: This example URL-encodes a short and simple string message. The only special value in this example is a space and it gets encoded to %20.
examples.input: Hello! This is just a string, nothing more.

examples.title: URL-encode an Actual URL
examples.description: This example URL-encodes a string that also happens to be a valid web link. Special characters in this example are a colon, slash, question mark and equals sign.
examples.input: https://www.browserling.com/about?from=tools

examples.title: Encode All Characters
examples.description: In this example, we've enabled the option that encodes absolutely all characters in a string to URL-encoding. This option makes non-special characters, such as letters get encoded to their hex codes prefixed by a percent sign.
examples.input: I can't believe it's not butter!

examples.title: String with Newlines
examples.description: This example URL-escapes a string that has newlines in it. It still works as expected and all newline symbols get converted to %0A percent codes. Note that browsers use a single NL (0x0a) character for newlines.
examples.input:
foo
bar
baz

buttons.label: Encode Non-special Characters
buttons.comment:
If you select this option, then
all characters in the input
string will be converted to
URL-encoding (not just special).
buttons.name: encode-all-chars

tools.title: URL-decode a String
tools.name: String URL Decoder
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that URL-decodes a string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string URL unescaper. Load a string and get it URL-decoded.
tools.long_desc: Free online string URL-decoder. Just load your string and it will automatically get URL-unescaped. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string URL-unescaper. Load a URL-encoded string, get a URL-decoded string. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly URL-unescape a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool URL-decodes a previously URL-encoded string. URL-decoding is the inverse operation of URL-encoding. All percent-encoded characters get decoded to characters that you can understand. Some of the most well known percent-encoded values are %20 for a space, %3a for a colon, %2f for a slash, and %3f for a question mark. The two digits following the percent sign are character's char code values in hex. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Unescape a Short Message
examples.description: This example URL-unescapes a URL-escaped string message. The escaped message only contains %20 (0x20) char code values and they get converted to spaces (0x20 is a space).
examples.input: well%20hello%20again!%20this%20string%20has%20spaces.%20yes%20it%20does.
examples.output: well hello again! this string has spaces. yes it does.

examples.title: URL-decode a URL
examples.description: This example URL-decodes a URL. URLs are also just strings so they can easily be decoded. As you can see, the escape code %3A is a colon, %2F is a slash, %3F is a question mark and %3D is an equals sign.
examples.input: https%3A%2F%2Fwww.browserling.com%2Ftools%3Ffrom%3Donlinetools

examples.title: Newlines Work, Too!
examples.description: This example URL-unescapes a string that has newlines in it. URL-encoding for a newline is the sequence %0A. Even if you're on a Windows system that uses two characters per newline (carriage return followed by a newline), in browsers it's always just the newline symbol %0A.
examples.input: one%0Aword%0Aper%0Aline%0Ais%0Athe%0Abest%0Away%0Ato%0Awrite
examples.output:
one
word
per
line
is
the
best
way
to
write

tools.name: String HTML Encoder
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that HTML-encodes a string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string HTML escaper. Load a string, get a HTML-encoded string.
tools.long_desc: Free online string HTML entity encoder. Just load your string and it will automatically get converted to HTML encoding. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string HTML-escaper. Load a string, get HTML-entities. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly convert a string to HTML entities.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool converts all special HTML characters in a string to HTML entities. For example, the symbol "<" gets encoded to "&lt;" and symbol "&" gets encoded to "&amp;". This is useful if you want to put HTML code in HTML code. The only way to do it is to escape the code first. You can also encode absolutely all string characters to HTML entities if you select the option to do so. If selected, this mode will find the numeric value of every character, convert it to hex (or decimal) base and append "&#x" (or "&#" in decimal) before it and ";" after it. For example, the letter "a" that has a numeric value of 0x61 in hex (or 97 in decimal) will get converted to "&#x61;" (or "&#97;" in decimal). This is useful if you want to obfuscate your message so that other people can't understand it by looking at it. Some characters have predefined names, such as the value "&euro;" that designates the euro character "€". You can display entity names by using the "Print Name References" option. You can also preserve the structure of lines in multi-line strings by activating the "Preserve Line Breaks" option. Stringabulous!

examples.title: String with HTML
examples.description: In this example, we HTML-escape a string that contains regular HTML code. Character < gets converted to &lt; (lt stands for less than) and character > gets converted to > (gt stands for greater than). All other characters don't change as they're not special in HTML.
examples.input: A paragraph a day, keeps the doctor away.

examples.title: Escape All Characters
examples.description: This example converts all letters in a string to hexadecimal HTML entities. This is accomplished by taking each letter's codepoint value and changing its base to hex.
examples.input: HTML is a great language.

examples.title: List of Countries
examples.description: This example encodes a list of countries to decimal HTML entities. It preserves newline characters and displays named HTML references, such as a comma (&comma;), a new line (&NewLine;), and a period (&period;).
examples.input:
USA,
Mexico,
Japan,
China,
Brazil,
India.

tools.card_desc: Quickly convert HTML entities to a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool converts all HTML entities in a string back to regular characters. An HTML entity starts with the ampersand character, followed by the hex code or short entity name of the character, followed by a semicolon. For example, the HTML entity for the less-than character "<" is "&lt;" and the entity for the ampersand character itself "&" is "&amp;". It also works with obfuscated HTML strings where all characters have been converted to hex notation. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Decode an HTML-encoded String
examples.description: This example converts HTML entities in an HTML-encoded string back to a regular string that you can read. The HTML entities here are &lt; that is the < character, &quot; that is the double-quote character and &gt; that is the > character.
examples.output:
Disney Land
A theme park located at the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.

examples.title: Unescape an Obfuscated HTML
examples.description: In this example, we unescape obfuscated HTML code. Every character in the input string is an HTML entity and in the output, you get a decoded string made out of English letters.
examples.output: HTML is a not great a language.

tools.card_desc: Quickly convert a string to base64 encoding.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool converts a plain string to base64 encoding. Base64 encoding uses only letters a-z, A-Z, 0-9 and plus, slash and equals sign characters. This encoding scheme takes every 6 bits of the input string and assigns one of 64 letters to it. It's easy to calculate that base64 produces a larger output than the original string. As every sextet of bits now takes one character, the overhead is 33%. In the options above, you can also set base64 encoding's output chunk size (line length). And coming soon, you'll be able to customize 63rd (plus) and 64th (slash) alphabet characters as well as change the padding character. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Hello World Base64
examples.description: This simple example encodes a "hello world" string message to base64. The ending "=" character is the padding character that makes sure base64 output is evenly divisible in groups of 4 characters.
examples.input: hello world

tools.card_desc: Quickly decode a base64-encoded string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool converts a base64-encoded string back to a human-readable string. In base64 encoding, every 4 symbols get converted to 3 human-readable characters. This makes base64 a very ineffective encoding as it uses one third more memory to store the encoded data. This utility also supports multi-line base64 where each line is of a certain length. The base64 encoding consists of lowercase and uppercase English alphabet, numbers and two extra symbols. That is 26+26+10+2 symbols, which is 64. Stringabulous!

tools.title: Convert a String to a Netstring
tools.name: Netstring Creator
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that converts a string to a netstring. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string to netstring converter. Load a string, get a netstring.
tools.long_desc: Free online string to netstring creator. Just load your string and it will automatically get converted to a netstring. Load a string – get a netstring. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just an awesome netstring encoder. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly construct a netstring from a regular string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This browser-based tool constructs a netstring from a regular string. A netstring is a safe and reliable encoding method for transmitting regular strings as byte streams over networks or for serialization. It counts the number of 8-bit units in the string and stores this number in front of the string for easy parsing. A netstring can be represented in two different formats – as a length-prefixed string or as a series of hexadecimal numbers. A length-prefixed string format begins with ASCII digits that indicate the length of the data (number of bytes), then a colon, then the string itself, and a comma at the end. For example, the word "butterfly" gets encoded to "9:butterfly," and an empty string gets encoded to "0:,". In the hex format, the input string is first converted to UTF8 bytes and then these bytes are printed as hexadecimal values with a pair of angle brackets around them. In this case, the word "butterfly" gets encoded to <39 3a 62 75 74 74 65 72 66 6c 79 2c> and the empty line gets encoded to <30 3a 2c>. If your string contains several words, then it can be encoded in two ways – word-by-word or as a single long string. If you enter several text lines in the input, you can encode them as a whole or separately line-by-line. These encoding methods are easy to control via the "Encode Words" and "Multi-line" options. You can also activate the "Double Protection" option, which runs the netstring algorithm on the result the second time. If your string contains duplicate spaces, you can get rid of them via the "Skip Repeated Spaces" option. Also, you can prettify whitespace characters by replacing newlines with the "↵" symbol, regular spaces with the "⎵" symbol, and tabs with the "⇥" symbol. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Encode Three Words
examples.description: In this example, we convert three simple words to a netstring. We encode each word individually and print them together. As you can see, each word is encoded as its letter count, followed by a colon character, the word itself, and a comma. The spaces between the words aren't encoded because it's easy to deduce where they go (in place of commas).
examples.input: every moment matters

examples.title: Recursive Netstring
examples.description: This example applies the double protection algorithm to the quote by Oscar Wilde. First, it creates netstrings of all words and then recursively creates another netstring from the previous netstring.
examples.input: This suspense is terrible. I hope it will last.

examples.title: Music Genres
examples.description: In this example, we encode a list of music genres and output them in the hexadecimal netstring notation. This notation is the hexadecimal representation of a regular netstring wrapped in angle brackets. First, each genre is converted to a netstring, then all characters of this netstring are converted to base-16, and are placed between angle brackets. As the multi-line mode is active, we get eight separate hex netstrings for each genre.
examples.input:
Rock
Electronic
Funk
Country
Latin
Reggae
Hip hop
House

examples.title: Bill Wilson's Quote
examples.description: In this example, we have loaded a quote by Bill Wilson as the input. Unfortunately, it contains many extra spaces that we don't really want to process. To remove them, we have activated the skip-duplicate spaces option. We also process each line and each word individually. As there are four lines and four words per line, we get sixteen netstrings in the output.
examples.input:
To  the world you
may be  one   person,
but to  one   person
you are the   world.

examples.title: List of Flowers
examples.description: This example constructs a recursive netstring of a list of flowers. First, it counts the number of chars in every flower name and constructs a netstring for every flower. Then, it finds the length of this netstring and constructs a second netstring from it. The output format is selected as a hex-byte-string that prints the netstring chars as hex sequences between angle brackets.
examples.input:
Tulip
Bluebell
Rose
Snowdrop
Orchid
Peony
Chrysanthemum
Lily
Lotus

examples.title: Holiday Checklist
examples.description: In this example, we create one long netstring from nine shorter strings. The input contains different whitespaces and to make it more readable, we replace spaces with "⎵", tabs with "⇥", and newlines with "↵". Note that the regular space char has a length of 1 and contains one byte "0x20" but the UTF-8 symbol "⎵" is represented as three bytes "0xe2 0x8e 0xb5", so it has a length of 3. Similarly, tabs "⇥" have the length of 3 and so do newlines as "↵" has the length of 3.
examples.input:
passport	✓
sun cream	✗
swimming suit	✓
money		✓
medicine	✗
camera		✗
mobile phone	✓
a good book	✗
toothbrush	✓

tools.title: Convert a Netstring to a String
tools.name: Netstring Decoder
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that converts a netstring to a string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a netstring decoder. Load a netstring, get a string.
tools.long_desc: Free online netstring to string converter. Just load your netstring and it will automatically get decoded to a regular string. Load a netstring – get a string. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just an awesome netstring decoder. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly decode a netstring and output its contents.
tools.this_tool_desc: This browser-based utility decodes netstrings. It can parse both netstring formats – length-prefixed netstrings and angle bracket-wrapped hexadecimal netstrings. If the input has a length-prefixed format, it removes the byte length prefix, the colon symbol, and the trailing comma, and returns the encapsulated data. If the inputs have a hex format, then it removes the angle brackets, converts hex bytes to a byte stream, interprets it as UTF8-encoded data and returns the encapsulated Unicode string. If the input data contains multiple netstrings, they can be decoded and merged together in the output or they can be separated by space characters. The "Separate Words with Spaces" option controls this behavior. If the input netstring has been recursively encoded and has double protection, then it can be decoded twice by enabling the "Double Decode" option. You can also unbeautify special characters "↵" (newline), "⎵" (space), and "⇥" (tab). Stringabulous!

examples.title: Decode Five Words
examples.description: This example decodes a netstring-encoded John Lennon quote. The quote contains five words that have been encoded word-by-word. To do the conversion from a netstring to a string, it removes the byte lengths and colons before the words and commas after the words. It separates the words with a space character and prints a clean, well-formatted sentence.
examples.input: 3:All,3:you,4:need,2:is,5:love.,

examples.title: Orders of Magnitude of Time
examples.description: In this example, the input contains eight netstrings that have the hexadecimal form. Each netstring is on its own line and the lines are decoded one-by-one. It's easy to recognize the input format as each line starts and ends with an angle bracket. To find the contents, the bytes are converted to characters using a UTF8 decoder. It turns out that the list contains time units.
examples.output:
century
year
month
week
day
hour
minute
second

examples.title: The Largest Deserts
examples.description: This example loads a recursive netstring that contains beautified whitespace characters. To break the recursion, we use the double-decode option, which performs the decoding process twice. We also activate options to convert Unicode whitespaces to regular whitespaces. These options print a physical line break instead of the "↵" symbol, a physical tab instead of the "⇥" symbol, and a physical space instead of the "⎵" symbol.

Desert		Area (km²)
Antarctic	14,200,000
Arctic		13,900,000
Sahara		9,100,000
Arabian		2,600,000
Gobi		1,300,000
Patagonian	670,000

tools.name: String Escaper
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that escapes a string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string escaper. Load a string, escape a string.
tools.long_desc: Free online string escaper. Just load your string and it will automatically get backslash-escaped. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string slash-escaper. Load a string, slash-escape a string. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly quote a string with backslashes.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool implements PHP's addslashes function in JavaScript. It works entirely in your browser and what it does is it adds slashes to a string to escape special characters, such as backslashes, tabs, newlines, single quotes, and double quotes. Internally, it takes the input string and checks if the current character is special and if it is, then it adds a backslash before it. Stringabulous!

examples.description: This example adds backslashes before quotes and newlines.

tools.title: Slash-unescape a String
tools.name: String Unescaper
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that unescapes a string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string unescaper. Load a string, unescape a string.
tools.long_desc: Free online string unescaper. Just load your string and it will automatically get all backslashes removed. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string slash-unescaper. Load a string, slash-unescape a string. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly un-quote a backslash-quoted string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool implements PHP's stripslashes function in JavaScript. It works entirely in the browser and it removes slashes from a previously slash-escaped string. Its JavaScript implementation uses a simple state machine that changes the state whenever it sees a backslash. In this state, it knows that the next character should be treated specially. For example, if the next character is a "t", then it was the "\t" tab escape code, or if the next char is a "n", then it was the "\n" newline escape code. It then removes the backslash, expands the escape sequence to its raw value and returns to the previous state. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Un-escape Quoted Symbols
examples.description: This example removes all backslashes from a string. They include a backslash-escaped single quote and a backslash-escaped newline.

examples.output:
'Mess with the best,
die like the rest.'

tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that tests a string with a regex. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string regexp tester. Load a string – do a regex check.
tools.long_desc: Free online string regular expression tester. Just enter your string and a regular expression and this utility will automatically check if the string matches the given regexp. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just an awesome regex tester. Load a string – perform a regex check. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly check if a string matches a regular expression.
tools.this_tool_desc: This web application checks whether the given string matches the given regular expression. If so, it prints "true", if not, it prints "false". You can enter a regular expression in the options. The standard regexp format is "/pattern/flags", where flags are optionally "g", "i", "m", "s", "u", and "y". The "g" flag looks for all matches, the "i" flag makes matching case-insensitive, the "m" flag enables multi-line mode (in this case the multi-string option, described below must be disabled), the "s" flag makes the dot regular expression character match the newline character (in this case the multi-string option, must also be disabled), the "u" flag enables Unicode support, and the "y" flag enables sticky matching. When entering a regular expression, you can also skip slashes and flags and just enter "pattern" for easier and faster use. If you want to test several lines at once, use the multi-string option. It shows the status of each entered string on each line. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Test a Spoofed String
examples.description: This example tests the authenticity of a string. It checks whether all letters belong to the English alphabet. This is done using the regular expression /^[A-Za-z ]+$/. Here, "^" denotes the beginning of a string, "[A-Za-z ]+" corresponds to uppercase and lowercase letters of the Latin alphabet as well as a space character, and "$" denotes the end of a string. Surprisingly, the result of the test is false. It's because this string is not authentic and contains Unicode homoglyphs. Instead of the English letter "a", there's a fake Cyrillic letter "а".
examples.input: Moon аnd Stаrs

examples.title: Check Binary Values
examples.description: This example tests binary values. It activates the multi-string mode to get the status of all input numbers at once. It uses the regular expression /^[01]+$/g, which accepts only the digits "0" and "1" in a string. It is easy to see in the output that the 2nd, 6th, and 8th values are not binary numbers because they contain the English letters "I", "o", and "l".

true

tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that extracts substring. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a substring extractor. Load a string, get a substring.
tools.long_desc: Free online substring extractor. Just enter your string and this utility will automatically extract a string fragment of the given length from the given position. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a substring extractor. Load a string – get a substring. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly extract a fragment of a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This web application extracts a substring from a string. It cuts the characters starting from the "start" position and ends the cut when it counts "length" characters. Both "start" and "length" can be specified in the options. For example, if the string is "Penguin" and the start is 5 and the length is 2, then the extracted substring is "ui". Starting position can take both positive and negative values. For example, if in the same penguin example the start was -4, then it would mean that we should start trimming the string from the fourth character from the end, and we would get the substring "gu". Length can also be negative. The length sign indicates the cutting direction. If the sign is "+" then truncation is to the right, if the sign is "-", then it's to the left. For example, if the start is 3 and the length is -2, then we get the substring "en". It is also possible that both variables are negative. For example, the start -3 and length -4 will give the substring "engu". If you want to truncate the beginning part of the string, just leave the length field empty, or enter the "-" sign to truncate the end part of the string. To quickly get substrings of many strings, activate the "Multi-line Mode". In this case, each string on each line will get truncated. We also have an additional option that reverses characters in the output substring. Stringabulous!

tools.title: Printf a String
tools.name: String Printf
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that printf's strings. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string formatter. Load strings, apply printf on strings.
tools.long_desc: Free online string printf formatter. Just load your string and it will automatically get formatted using the sprintf function. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string formatter. Load a string, apply printf on it. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly apply printf (or sprintf) on strings.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool applies the sprintf (or printf) function on strings. You can specify the sprintf format in the options and then every string on every line will get formatted according to this format. Some of the valid formats are %s that will return either the entire string or one word, then %d that will match a positive or a negative integer, then %f that will match a floating-point number, and %b, %o, and %h that will convert the input string to binary, octal, and hex. Some of the arguments take a numeric modifier. For example, %08b will pad a binary number to full bytes (8 positions) and %15s will left-pad a string to the width of 15 characters. The numeric modifiers can also sometimes be negative. For example, %-15s will right-pad a string to 15 positions. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Numeric Strings
examples.description: This example formats five numbers using the "%04d" sprintf format. This format zero-pads the input strings (as numbers) on the left side to be at least 4 chars long. If the input number is longer than 4 digits, then it's printed as-is.

examples.title: The String Flag %s
examples.description: This example formats strings using the "%10s" printf format. This format right-aligns the input strings by padding each string with spaces on the left until its length reaches 10 characters. Notice that if a string has multiple words, then the %s format only matches the first word. If any of the input strings is longer than 10 characters, then it's left unchanged.
examples.input:
ant
wasp
insect
bee
termite
i hate insects
i_hate_spiders
examples.output:
ant
      wasp
    insect
       bee
   termite
         i
i_hate_spiders

examples.title: Floating-point Strings
examples.description: This example formats strings that are actually floating-point numbers. It uses the "%.2f" format that leaves only two decimal places after the dot. This operation is effectively rounding to the closest number with a precision of one one-hundredth.

tools.name: String Splitter
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free, and easy to use online tool that splits strings. Just load your string here and it'll get split into pieces.
tools.long_desc: Free online string splitter. Just load your string here and it will automatically get split into multiple substrings. You can split it by one or more characters, a regular expression, by length, or by substring count. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly split a string into pieces.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool splits the input string into pieces. You can switch between various splitting methods – using a character, a regular expression, a fragment length, or a number of parts. If you want to split a string by a specific symbol, select the "Split by a Character" option and enter the split symbol below it (by default, it's the space symbol). If you need more advanced control of splitting, choose the "Split by a Regular Expression" option. It allows you to fine-tune the matches and extract more complex chunks. If you need to get string fragments of a certain length, then select the "Split by Length" option and specify the number of characters you want in each part. If you need to get an exact number of chunks in the output, select the "Split in Multiple Parts" option and specify the number of parts you want to obtain. By default, the substrings are output one per line but you can set any character that joins them together in the options. You can also wrap the split substrings in any characters. For example, you can enclose them in quotes (e.g., "a", "b", "c") or wrap them in brackets (e.g., [a], [b], [c]) by specifying the left and right wrappers in the options. Stringabulous!

examples.description: The given input string in this example is split by the space character into individual words. Every word is printed on its own line.

examples.output:
foo
bar
baz
qux
quux
quuz
corge

examples.title: Split a String by a Regexp
examples.description: This example splits a string into pieces by using a regular expression. The regular expression is \d+, which means "use one or more digits as separating symbols". As you can see, that's exactly what happens and the output is all substrings between the digits.

examples.description: In this example, we're splitting the input by length to get string fragments of the same width. We set the line width to 6 characters and display each substring on a new line. The last line has only two characters because the input length is not exactly divisible by 6.

e hand

idence

examples.title: Split a String into 5 Equal Parts
examples.description: In this example, we load the string "HELLO" spelled in its binary representation that consists of only ones and zeros. Since the string does not have a byte separator, it's difficult to tell where one byte ends and the next byte starts. To make it easier to understand, we split it into 5 equal parts (each part corresponds to one letter of the word "HELLO"). As a result, in the output, we get 5 space-separated bytes with 8 bits in each byte.

examples.title: Wrap the Substrings in Brackets
examples.description: In this example, we split an idiomatic expression into words and then wrap them in square brackets. We use the regular expression-based split method and specify the regex "\s+" as the string delimiter. Once the string has been split into substrings, the symbol "[" is added before each substring and the symbol "]" is added after each substring.

tools.card_desc: Quickly center a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This browser-based tool centers a string to the given width of a line. You can specify any number of characters for the line width but if the string is longer than your value, this tool does nothing and just returns your input string. You can also change the symbols used for centering the string on the left and right. If the specified line length minus the input string length is not divisible by two, then one of the sides will have an extra centering character. In this case, we have a useful option that allows you to choose which side to tilt the centering to. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Center a Multi-line String
examples.description: This example centers a multiline string. Each line of the string gets treated separately and is centered to the width of 40 characters. Usually, there is an equal number of spaces on the left and right sides of the line but in some cases, there is one more space on the right side because the "Extra Char on the Right" option is selected here.

llama
okapi
mule
zebra

examples.title: Custom Centering Symbols
examples.description: This example centers a single string and uses different symbols on the left and right. On the left, it uses a dash. On the right, it uses a tilde. A simple calculation shows that it puts the same number of symbols on both sides. The required length of the string is 26 (specified in options), the length of the input string is 6 (length of "winamp"). The difference, 26 - 6 = 20, is the number of characters to add on both sides. As there are two sides, we get 20 / 2 = 10 characters per side. As the number 10 is a whole number, we get ten "-" symbols on the left and ten "~" on the right. However, if there were, for example, 21 characters per side, then one side would have an additional symbol (one side would get 11 symbols and the other side 10).
examples.input: winamp

examples.description: In this example, we center a list of cartoons released by Disney Animation Studios. We set the total line length to 24 characters and specify the "<" symbol on the left and the ">" symbol on the right. On the lines where the filling is uneven, we put an additional character on the right. You can toggle between the extra char on the left / right options to see the effect of this option.

tools.title: Slice a String
tools.name: String Slicer
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that slices string. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string slicer. Load a string, slice string.
tools.long_desc: Free online string slicer. Just enter your string and this utility will automatically extract a fragment from it. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string slicer. Load a string – slice a string. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly fetch a part of a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This browser-based program slices strings like a hot knife slices butter. It extracts all characters from a string that are in the range [start, end]. Both range parts are included in the match. For example, if you set the start to 4 and end to 5, and your input string is "goodjob" will turn into a substring "dj". If one of the parameters is missing, then the extracted piece extends to the last (or first) character of the string. For example, for the range [2, ⌴] we get the slice "oodjob" and for the range [⌴, 3] we get the slice "goo". Starting and ending values can also be negative. When working with negative parameters, the last element is the minus first (-1), the second to last is the minus second (-2), and so on. For example, if the range is [-3, -1] then the cropped string will be "job". Combinations of different signs are also acceptable. For example, the interval [3, -4] will turn into "od" and the interval [-3, 6] will turn into "jo". The order of letters in the output doesn't change, they always go from left to right. If you need to swap characters' positions, use the "Reverse Symbols" option. You can also use the "Multiline Slicing" option when working with multiple lines. In this case, individual strings on new lines will be sliced independently. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Slice a Phrase
examples.description: This example slices a string using a range with positive start and length values. It starts the slice from the eleventh position, which corresponds to the letter "j", and ends the slice at the seventeenth position, which corresponds to the letter "y". As a result, this tool returns a substring with a single word "journey".
examples.input: Life is a journey, not a race.

examples.title: Slice Alphabets
examples.description: In this example, we use a slicing mechanism to extract the last five letters from the Latin, Cyrillic, and Greek alphabets. As each alphabet has a different number of letters, we use the negative values in the range. The position "-1" corresponds to the last character of the alphabet and the position "-5" corresponds to the fifth letter from the end, so we're slicing backward. We also activate the multi-line slicing mode to get substrings with the last five uppercase and lowercase letters from the alphabets of three different languages.
examples.input:
ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

examples.title: Slice Web Address
examples.description: This example cleans the input web addresses from the "https" (secure http) protocol, "www" (world wide web) prefixes, and trailing slashes, and extracts just the domain names. As the beginning part of each line is the same ("https://www.") and is 12 characters long, the app sets the starting position to 13. As the end part of each line is also the same (it's a trailing slash), the app sets the ending position to -2, which is the 2nd character from the end. Thus, all characters from the beginning of the string to the 13th position, as well as the last character, are deleted, and only the domain names are returned from each line.

https://www.facebook.com/
https://www.youtube.com/

https://www.wikipedia.org/
https://www.amazon.com/
https://www.netflix.com/

tools.card_desc: Quickly add a pair of quotes around a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This online tool adds quotation marks to the left side and the right side of the given string (or multiple strings, entered one per line). Enclosing a string in quotation marks sets the boundaries of the string, highlights direct speech, and allows processing the data in a textual context (used in programming). To quote a string, you can use single quotes (e.g., 'fox', ‘fox’, or ‹fox›), double quotes (e.g., "fox", “fox”, or «fox»), backticks (e.g., `fox`), or other symmetric characters (e.g., 「fox」 or 【 fox】). Since the left and right quotation marks can be different, in the options, you will find two separate fields for the left and right quotation marks. You will also find several additional options to customize the quoting rules. In particular, if the input string already has quotation marks, then via the "Double Quotation" option, you can choose whether to quote such strings again. If the input data has multiple strings on different lines, then via the "Multiline Quoting" option, you can choose whether to quote each line individually or quote everything as a single long string. Finally, if the input text contains empty strings, then via the "Empty String Quoting" option, you can choose whether to quote strings that do not have any visible characters in them (such as empty lines or lines that contain only spaces). Stringabulous!

By enabling the "Multiline Quoting" and "Empty String Quoting" options, each line is enclosed in quotation marks, including the empty separator string on the second line. The left-quote symbol is set to the "Left White Lenticular Bracket 〖" and the right-quote symbol is set to the "Right White Lenticular Bracket 〗". These symbols can be found in the Unicode table.

tools.long_desc: Free online string quote remover. Just load your quoted string here and it will automatically get unwrapped and the left and right quotes will disappear from it. In the options below, you can set the quote marks that surround your string as well as configure the unquoting rules. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly remove quotes around a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This online tool removes quotation marks from the given string (or multiple strings, entered one per line). It can remove arbitrary opening quotes (on the left side of a string) and closing quotes (on the right side of a string) and the main option that you'll be changing in this tool is the "Quotes to Remove" option. Here you can specify all possible quotation marks that appear around the strings that you load in the input. For example, they can be regular single or double quotation marks (such as 'book' or "book"), single or double curved quotation marks (such as ‘book’ or “book”), and single or paired angle quotation marks (such as ‹book› or «book»). You can list all these quotation marks and others in the options field (joined together, one after another without spaces). To ensure the complete removal of all quotation marks, the tool provides the "Thorough Unquoting" option. It will be handy if your strings contain multiple levels of quotation marks, such as ‘‹book›’. This feature will remove all of them at once. Another useful option offered by the tool is "Trim Unquoted Strings". It allows you to clear any accidental surrounding spaces that might appear in the strings after the quotes have been removed. For example, if the string is "‹ book ›", then if this option is off, you will get " book " in the output (there are spaces on the left and right of this string). But if the option is on, then the output will be "book" (without any surrounding spaces). To make it easy to work with multiline strings, the tool implements the "Multiline Unquoting" option. This feature enables multi-string processing, where each string appears on its own input line. When this option is on, the quotation marks will be removed in a multiline context for each string. Stringabulous!

tools.card_desc: Quickly remove spaces, tabs, and newlines from a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool removes all whitespace characters from a string. The whitespace characters aren't just spaces but include several different types of characters, such as a tab, newline, line feed, form feed, no-break space, en space, em space, and others. The program can either remove all these whitespace characters at once or delete one or more specific types of whitespace. When the "Delete All Whitespaces" mode is activated, you will get an output string with all whitespace characters removed. When you select the "Delete Specific Whitespaces" mode, you can individually control the removal of spaces, tabs, and newlines. Additionally, you can enable the option to remove custom whitespace characters. Here, you can list rare whitespace characters such as Rightwards Bar-arrow "⇥" (representing a tab), Open Box "␣" (representing a space), Downwards Arrow "↵" (representing a line break), and any others. Furthermore, in place of the removed whitespace characters, you can insert a custom connecting symbol that will join all parts of the string. Stringabulous!

tools.title: Change String Case
tools.name: String Case Changer
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free, and easy to use online tool that changes the case in a string. No intrusive ads, popups, or nonsense, just a string case changer. Load a string, get a string in a new case.
tools.long_desc: Free online string case changer. Just load your string and it will automatically get converted to the case you want. There are no intrusive ads, popups, or nonsense, just a string capitalization changer. Load a string, get a new string with a new case. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly change the case of characters in a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool changes the case of letters in a string. You can use the dropdown list in the options to select one of a dozen case changing algorithms. For example, if you need to change all letters to the small letters in a string, activate the "lowercase" mode. To convert all letters to capital letters, use the "UPPERCASE" option. If your string is a heading and you do not know how to correctly capitalize the characters, select the "Title Case" option. It parses the string and capitalizes important words and leaves short words non-capitalized. If you have multi-sentence data and you want to correctly capitalize sentences, then activate the "True case" mode. It turns the first character in each sentence and the word "I" to uppercase and the remaining symbols are converted to lowercase. If you need to create a case chaos in a string, enable the "ChAOs cAsE" option. It randomly assigns a case to every character. If you want to get the exact opposite case of the input data, then the "Inverse Case" option will be helpful. It turns small letters into big letters and big letters into small ones. The "WaVy-1" and "wAvY-2" modes alternate case for each glyph in a string, starting with upper case glyph (WaVy-1) or lower case glyph (wAvY-2). The "Word Case" option capitalizes the first symbol of each word and the "reversE worD casE" turns only the last letter of the word to uppercase. If you want to apply one of these modes to several strings independently, activate the "Multiline" mode. In this mode, each line is treated as a new string and modes such as "True case" and "Wavy" will operate correctly when the string spans multiple lines. Stringabulous!

buttons.label: Case
buttons.comment: Select string case.
buttons.name: case

buttons.label: Multiline Mode
buttons.comment:
Change case in each
line individually.
buttons.name: multiline

buttons.value:
Lower case example:
"keep calm and carry on."

Upper case example:
"KEEP CALM AND CARRY ON."

"keeP CALm aND CaRrY on."

Title case example:
"Keep Calm and Carry On."

True case example:
"Keep calm and carry on."

Wavy-1 case example:
"KeEp CaLm AnD cArRy On."

Wavy-2 case example:
"kEeP cAlM aNd CaRrY oN."

Inverse case example:
"kEEp caLM" → "KeeP CAlm"

Word case example:
"Keep Calm And Carry On."

Reverse word case example:
"keeP calM anD carrY oN."

examples.title: Title Case
examples.description: In this example, we activate the option "Title Case". This mode creates a correct word capitalization for use in titles and headings.
examples.input: and so the adventure begins

examples.title: True Case
examples.description: This example fixes the case of a multi-sentence string. It uses the "True Case" option that capitalizes only the first character of the sentence and turns all other characters into lowercase.
examples.input: dOn't BE THe sAMe. be bETter. or best.
examples.output: Don't be the same. Be better. Or best.

examples.title: Word Case
examples.description: This example uses the "Word Case" option to convert every first letter of every word to uppercase. The remaining part of the word is printed in lowercase.
examples.input: if you can dream it, you can do it. walt disney
examples.output: If You Can Dream It, You Can Do It. Walt Disney

examples.title: Upper Case
examples.description: In this example, we set the case option to "Uppercase" to convert each symbol in the string to a capital symbol.
examples.input: Keep it cool.

examples.title: Lower Case
examples.description: This example converts a string with a broken case into a lowercase string via the "Lowercase" option.
examples.input: LIvE the MOMenT.

examples.title: Inverse Case
examples.description: In this example, we get exactly the opposite case of the initial case. This is achieved via the "Inverse Case" option. This option flips the case of every character and creates small chars in place of large chars and large chars instead of small chars.
examples.input: bETtER LatE tHAn NEVer.

examples.title: Chaos Case
examples.description: This example creates a case chaos in Donna Marie Robie's quote. The case of each character is determined randomly by the computer.
examples.input: People are like snowflakes, no two are ever alike.
examples.output: peoPle ARE liKE snOwFLakES, no tWo ARe eVer alIke.

examples.title: Wavy-1 Case
examples.description: This example creates a wave-like pattern in the letters of the input string. It starts with a large letter, then switches to a small letter, then switches again to large, then to a small again, and so on.
examples.input: Time flies when you're having fun.
examples.output: TiMe FlIeS wHeN yOu'rE hAvInG fUn.

examples.title: Wavy-2 Case
examples.description: This example also creates a wave-like pattern. It's almost the same as the previous one but here the opposite case is used for each symbol: small, large, small, large, and so on.
examples.input: Love is the beauty of the soul. — Augustine of Hippo
examples.output: lOvE iS tHe BeAuTy Of ThE sOuL. — aUgUsTiNe Of HiPpO

examples.title: Reverse Word Case
examples.description: In this example, we apply an extraordinary case format to Frank Zappa's quote. The option "Reverse Word Case" first turns all letters of all words into lowercase and then changes the ending letter of all words to uppercase.
examples.input: So many books, so little time.
examples.output: sO manY bookS, sO littlE timE.

examples.title: Multiline True Case
examples.description: In this example, we combine the "True case" and "Multiline" options and apply them to Dan Brown's quote. As a result, all lines and all sentences begin with a capital letter. If the "Multiline" option was off, then only true sentences would begin with a capital letter and new lines in the middle of sentences would be ignored.
examples.input:
everything is possible.
the impossible
just takes longer.
examples.output:
Everything is possible.
The impossible
Just takes longer.

tools.card_desc: Quickly convert a string to a JSON string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool converts a string to a JSON string. This is done by calling JSON.stringify() function on the input string. This function adds double quotes at the beginning and end of the input string and escapes special JSON characters. In particular, a newline is replaced by the \n character, a tab is replaced by the \t character, a backslash is replaced by two backslashes \\, and a backslash is placed before each quotation mark. Stringabulous!

tools.title: Create a Palindrome from a String
tools.name: String Palindrome Creator
tools.meta_desc: Simple, free and easy to use online tool that creates palindromes from strings. No intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a palindrome creator. Load a string, make it a palindrome.
tools.long_desc: Free online string palindrome creator. Just load your string and it will automatically get converted to a palindrome. There are no intrusive ads, popups or nonsense, just a string palindrome generator. Load a string, make it a palindrome. Created for developers by developers from team Browserling.
tools.card_desc: Quickly create a palindrome from a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool creates a palindrome from the given string. It does it by generating a copy of the string, reversing it, and appending it at the end of the original string. This method creates a palindrome with the last character duplicated twice. There is also another way to do it, which deletes the first letter of the reversed copy. In this case, when the string and the copy are joined together, you also get a palindrome but without the repeating last character. You can compare the two types of palindromes by switching between them in the options. You can also enable the multi-line mode that will create palindromes of every string on every line. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Hello Palindrome!
examples.description: This example creates a palindrome from a short string that says "hello". It activates the "Skip Last Character" option to generate a palindrome without repeating the last character "o" and the output is "hellolleh".
examples.input: hello

examples.title: Palindrome from Parentheses
examples.description: In this example, we create a palindrome from three pairs of matching parentheses "()()()". Most people would think that the palindrome of this string is "()()()()()()" but it's not. It's actually "()()())()()(". The last character of the input string is the right bracket and when it gets duplicated it doesn't get reversed but gets copied. As a result, the closed pairs of brackets break and you get "))" instead of "()". The same thing happens with the first bracket and in the full palindrome copy, you get two closed pairs of parentheses surrounded by open parenthesis on the sides.

examples.title: Multiple Palindromes
examples.description: This example enables the multi-line mode and produces multiple palindromes for every string on every line, including the famous taco cat on the last line.

tools.card_desc: Quickly generate all monograms of a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool generates unigrams from a string. A unigram is an n-gram where n=1 and it consists of all single text items. These items can be either words or characters. This tool both unigram types. The first one builds monograms by splitting the string into words. That is, each word becomes a separate entity in the sequence. The second one splits the string into characters. In this case, the sequence consists of independent letters, where spaces are replaced with the "_" character. The tool also has an option for quickly converting all 1-grams to lowercase and an option for removing punctuation. Stringabulous!

tools.card_desc: Quickly generate all digrams of a string.
tools.this_tool_desc: This tool generates bigrams (also known as digrams and 2-grams) from a string. A bigram is a pair of two consecutive words or characters in a string. Bigrams are often used in machine learning and natural language processing to analyze and understand the text. This tool lets you generate two variations of bigrams. It can generate bigrams for all sentences, or create separate bigrams for each sentence alone. You can choose the sentence processing mode in the options above. It also allows you to easily remove the punctuation marks from 2-grams by listing the characters you want to get rid of. By default, all bigrams will have lowercase letters, but you can toggle this behavior. And finally, you can adjust the separator between bigram words and characters. Stringabulous!

examples.title: Pairs of Words

We've also removed all existing punctuation marks and retain the original case of letters. Individual words in a bigram are separated by an underscore and bigrams themselves are separated by a dot.

examples.output: The_most. most_beautiful. beautiful_things. things_in. in_the. the_world. world_cannot. cannot_be. be_seen. seen_or. or_touched. They_are. are_felt. felt_with. with_the. the_heart. Antoine_de. de_Saint-Exupery. Saint-Exupery_The. The_Little. Little_Prince
